name: Different Differences
description:
An array 
    a
 consisting of 
    k
 integers is strictly increasing if

    a_1 < a_2 < 
    … < a_k
. For example, the arrays 
    [1, 3, 5]
,

    [1, 2, 3, 4]
, 
    [3, 5, 6]
 are strictly increasing; the arrays 
    [2,
    2]
, 
    [3, 7, 5]
, 
    [7, 4, 3]
, 
    [1, 2, 2, 3]
 are not. For a
strictly increasing array 
    a
 of 
    k
 elements, let's denote the
characteristic as the number of different elements in the array 
    [a_2 - a_1,
    a_3 - a_2, 
    …, a_k - a_k-1]
. For example, the characteristic of the
array 
    [1, 3, 4, 7, 8]
 is 
    3
 since the array 
    [2, 1, 3, 1]

contains 
    3
 different elements: 
    2
, 
    1
 and 
    3
. You are
given two integers 
    k
 and 
    n
 (
    k 
    ≤ n
). Construct an
increasing array of 
    k
 integers from 
    1
 to 
    n
 with maximum
possible characteristic. Input The first line contains one integer 
    t

(
    1 
    ≤ t 
    ≤ 819
) — the number of test cases. Each test case
consists of one line containing two integers 
    k
 and 
    n
 (
    2 
    ≤ k
    
    ≤ n 
    ≤ 40
). Output For each test case, print 
    k
 integers — the
elements of the strictly increasing array 
    a
 with the maximum possible
characteristic. If there are multiple answers, print any of them. Example
Input 7 5 9 4 12 3 3 3 4 4 4 4 6 8 11 Output 1 3 4 7 8 2 4 7 12 1 2 3 1 3 4 1
2 3 4 2 4 5 6 1 2 3 5 6 7 8 11
